fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Deligne's "The fundamental group of the projective line minus three points" › \mathbb {Z}(n)-torsors

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The study of the fundamental group of \mathbb {P} ^1 \setminus \{ 0,1, \infty \} reveals, for each k \geqslant2, a torsor P_{1,k} for \mathbb {Z} (k) on \operatorname {Spec} ( \mathbb {Z} ). We will describe these torsors in this section. The relation with \pi _1 will be explained in [minus-three-points-16] (see [minus-three-points-16.23]) and the calculations to justify this will be given in [minus-three-points-19]. We will then describe the torsors P_{d,k} for \mathbb {Z} (k) on \operatorname {Spec} ( \mathbb {Q} ( \sqrt [d]{1})), given by an analogous construction ([minus-three-points-16.28]).

The sum of the P_{d,k} and of (-1)^k times its symmetry under \zeta \mapsto \zeta ^{-1} is torsion. This is essentially equivalent to the adelic integral formulas for the value of the Dirichlet L functions at negative integers: [minus-three-points-3.6], [minus-three-points-3.8], [minus-three-points-3.9], and [minus-three-points-3.14]. A geometric interpretation, which allows us to reprove these formulas, will be given in [minus-three-points-18].
A geometric interpretation of the relations of distributions ([minus-three-points-3.13]) will be given in [minus-three-points-17].

Let N be an integer; we will describe P_{ \mathbb {Z} {/}(N)}. For z \in \mathbb {C} with z \neq1, let T_N(z) \coloneqq K(1-z)_{ \mathbb {Z} {/}(N)} be the \mathbb {Z} {/}N(1)-torsor of N-th roots of 1-z. For z=1, we set T_N(1)=K(1/N)_{ \mathbb {Z} {/}(N)}. This convention ensures that the sum of the T_N( \alpha ) for \alpha ^N=1 is trivialised: we have \frac {1}{N} \prod (1- \alpha ) = 1.

For non-real negative z, we define the principal determination of z \mapsto z^{1/N}, and denote by z^{1/N}, that which takes the value of 1 at 1. The morphism of torsors \operatorname {comp} _{ \mathbb {Z} {/}(N), { \mathrm {B}} } sends u_ { \mathrm {B}} to the point u of P_{ \mathbb {Z} {/}(N)} defined by the (1- \alpha )^{1/N} \in T( \alpha ): u_ { \mathrm {B}} \mapsto u = \sum \alpha ^{ \otimes (k-1)} ((1- \alpha )^{1/N}).

With this notation, the crystalline Frobenius \phi _p is given by
832Equationminus-three-points-3.2.7kminus-three-points-3.2.7k.xml3.2.7kminus-three-points-3.2 \phi _p^{-1}(0) = (k-1)!p^k \cdot \operatorname {vp} \ell _k^{(p)}(1). \tag{3.2.7k}

We have described the \mathbb {Z} {/}(N)(k)-torsor P_{ \mathbb {Z} {/}(N)} as a sum of torsors indexed by the N-th roots of 1. If N is a power of a prime number \ell, say N= \ell ^n, then we can again, thanks to , write it as a sum indexed by the set \mu (N)^ \times of primitive N-th roots of 1. Indeed, we have isomorphisms \begin {aligned} P_{ \mathbb {Z} {/}(N)} &= \sum _{ \alpha ^N=1} \ldots \\ &= \sum _{a=1}^n \sum _{ \mu ( \ell ^a)^ \times } \ldots \\ &= \sum _{a=1}^n \sum _{ \alpha \in \mu ( \ell ^a)^ \times } \alpha ^{ \otimes (k-1)} \sum _{ \beta ^{ \ell ^{n-a}}= \alpha } T_N( \beta ). \end {aligned} In this sum, \beta runs over, for each a, all the primitive N-th roots of 1, whence \begin {aligned} P_{ \mathbb {Z} {/}(N)} &= \sum _{ \beta \in \mu (N)^ \times } \beta ^{ \otimes (k-1)}T_N( \beta ) \cdot \sum _{a=1}^n \ell ^{(n-a)(k-1)} \\ &= \frac {1}{1- \ell ^{k-1}} \sum _{ \beta \in \mu (N)^ \times } \beta ^{ \otimes (k-1)}T_N( \beta ). \end {aligned} The cohomology class of P_{ \mathbb {Z} {/}(N)} (for N= \ell ^n) in \operatorname {H} ^1( \operatorname {Spec} ( \mathbb {Q} ), \mathbb {Z} {/}(N)(k)) thus admits the following description. Let \mathbb {Q} ( \zeta ) be the cyclotomic field generated by a primitive N-th root of 1. In \operatorname {H} ^1( \operatorname {Spec} ( \mathbb {Q} ( \zeta )), \mathbb {Z} {/}N(1)), let \delta (1- \zeta ) be the Kummer coboundary of 1- \zeta. On \operatorname {Spec} ( \mathbb {Q} ( \zeta )), \zeta identifies the \mathbb {Z} {/}N(a) with one another, and we can think of \delta (1- \zeta ) as a class with values in \mathbb {Z} {/}N(k). More precisely, we consider \zeta ^{ \otimes (k-1)} \cup \partial (1- \zeta ) \in \operatorname {H} ^1( \operatorname {Spec} ( \mathbb {Q} ( \zeta )), \mathbb {Z} {/}N(k)). We have \operatorname {cl} (P_{ \mathbb {Z} {/} \ell ^n}) = \frac {1}{1- \ell ^{k-1}} \operatorname {Tr} _{ \mathbb {Q} ( \zeta )/ \mathbb {Q} }( \zeta ^{ \otimes (k-1)} \cup \partial (1- \zeta )) and the class of P_ \ell is the limit of these classes.

We denote by \zeta ^{(p)}(s) the \zeta function with its Eulerian factor at p removed: \zeta ^{(p)}(s) \coloneqq \sum _{p \nmid n} 1/n^s. We know that the values of \zeta ^{(p)}(s) on the negative integers are rational and admit a p-adic interpolation. More precisely,
Let \mathbb {C} _p be the completion of an algebraic closure of \mathbb {Q} _p. Then the characters \chi \colon \mathbb {Z} _p^ \times \to \mathbb {C} _p^ \times are the points of a rigid analytic space.
There exists exactly one rigid analytic function \zeta _p^{(p)}( \chi ), with a simple pole at \chi =(x \mapsto x^{-1}), such that \zeta _p^{(p)}(x \mapsto x^{-1}) = \zeta ^{(p)}(n) \in \mathbb {Q} for every integer n<0.

We set, for n \in \mathbb {Z} with n \neq1, \zeta _p^{(p)}(n) \coloneqq \zeta _p^{(p)}(x \mapsto x^{-1}). This notation differs from that of [C] or [Ko]: our \zeta _p^{(p)} is not a continuous p-adic function of the integer n. Instead, it is a continuous function of the character x \mapsto x^n, itself a continuous function of n if and only if we restrict n to an arithmetic progression of difference p-1. We have \zeta _p^{(p)}(n) = \lim _a \zeta ^{(p)}(n-(p-1)p^a). The trivial zeros of \zeta force \zeta _p^{(p)}(n)=0 for even n, i.e. for x \mapsto x^{-n} an even character. More generally, \zeta _p^{(p)}( \chi )=0 for even \chi.

With this notation, we have (cf. [C; Ko]) \operatorname {vp} \ell _k^{(p)}(1) = \zeta _p^{(p)}(k) and can be rewritten as
309Equationminus-three-points-3.4.1kminus-three-points-3.4.1k.xml3.4.1kminus-three-points-3.4 \phi _p^{-1}(0) = (k-1)! p^k \zeta _p^{(p)}(k). \tag{3.4.1k}
For k even, the torsor P_{1,k} is torsion, with order equal to the denominator of \frac {1}{2} \zeta (1-k).

Let P be a torsor for a realisation system M with integer coefficients. The fact that P is n-torsion means more than "every realisation is n-torsion". Let \frac {1}{n}M be the realisation system M \otimes \mathbb {Q}, endowed with the integer structure \frac {1}{n}M_ { \mathrm {B}}. It is isomorphic to M, by an isomorphism that sends M \hookrightarrow \frac {1}{n}M by n \colon M \to M. The fact that P is n-torsion thus implies that it becomes trivial under M \to \frac {1}{2}M. For M of weight \leqslant-1, this implies:
P_ { \mathrm {B}} + \frac {1}{n}M_ { \mathrm {B}} \cap F^0 P_ { \mathrm {DR}} \otimes \mathbb {C} \neq \phi (the intersection in P_ { \mathrm {B}} \otimes \mathbb {C} \xrightarrow { \sim } P_ { \mathrm {DR}} \otimes \mathbb {C}). The point of intersection x is then unique, since M_ { \mathrm {B}} \cap F^0(M_ { \mathrm {DR}} ) \otimes \mathbb {C} =0.
x \in F^0 P_{DR}, i.e. is defined over \mathbb {Q} for the \mathbb {Q}-structure { \mathrm {DR}}.
The image of x under \operatorname {comp} _{ \mathbb {A} ^ \mathrm {f} ,B} is fixed by Galois.
The image of x under \operatorname {comp} _{ { { \mathrm {cris}} \, \, p} , { \mathrm {DR}} } is fixed by \phi _p.

Suppose that F^0 M_ { \mathrm {DR}} =0. Then P_ { \mathrm {DR}} =M_ { \mathrm {DR}}, and we can identify P_ { \mathrm {B}} with a lateral class of M_ { \mathrm {B}} \subset M_ { \mathrm {DR}} \otimes \mathbb {C}. Condition (a) then becomes P_ { \mathrm {B}} \subset \frac {1}{n}M_ { \mathrm {B}}. We have x=0, and (b) is automatic. We can write (d) as \phi _p(0)=0. Let p \in P_ { \mathrm {B}}. Denote by p_M its image in \frac {1}{n}M_ { \mathrm {B}}, and set p^ \wedge = \operatorname {comp} _{ \widehat { \mathbb {Z}} , { \mathrm {B}} }(p) \in P_{ \widehat { \mathbb {Z}} } and (p_M)^ \wedge = \operatorname {comp} _{ \mathbb {A} ^ \mathrm {f} , { \mathrm {B}} }(p_M) \in M_ \mathbb {A} ^ \mathrm {f}. Condition (c) can then be written as
842Equationminus-three-points-3.6.1minus-three-points-3.6.1.xml3.6.1minus-three-points-3.6 \sigma p^ \wedge - p^ \wedge = ( \sigma-1 )(p_M)^ \wedge . \tag{3.6.1}

In , k is even, and we can take p=-(k-1)! \zeta (k), and is a Galois formula for -(c^k-1)(k-1)! \zeta (k) modulo N(2 \pi i)^k \mathbb {Z}. We recover a known formula expressing \zeta on the negative integers as an adelic integral.
The above description shows that, if P is of finite order, then its order can be read from its Hodge realisation.
